item.title: Self‐Regeneration and Self‐Healing in DNA Origami Nanostructures
item.dc:description: Inspired by nature's self‐repair mechanisms at the molecular level, Viktorija Glembockyte, Philip Tinnefeld et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202012986) applied dynamic self‐regeneration and damage specific self‐healing mechanisms to DNA origami nanostructures and show how they can lead to improved performance of nanorulers and brightness labels.
item.dc:creator: Michael Scheckenbach, Tom Schubert, Carsten Forthmann, Viktorija Glembockyte, Philip Tinnefeld
item.content:encoded: Inspired by nature's self‐repair mechanisms at the molecular level, Viktorija Glembockyte, Philip Tinnefeld et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202012986) applied dynamic self‐regeneration and damage specific self‐healing mechanisms to DNA origami nanostructures and show how they can lead to improved performance of nanorulers and brightness labels.
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:title: Self‐Regeneration and Self‐Healing in DNA Origami Nanostructures

item.title: Strain Engineering of MXene/CNT Hierarchical Porous Hollow Microsphere Electrocatalyst for High‐efficiency Lithium Polysulfides Conversion Process
item.dc:description: A tensile‐strained MXene/CNT porous microsphere was developed by Xin Wang, Zhongwei Chen et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202011493) as electrocatalyst for high‐performance lithium–sulfur batteries. A unique O–Ti–C interface was constructed on the MXene surface through a spray‐drying process and heat treatment to produce internal stress, inducing lattice distortion and enlargement of the Ti−Ti bond.
item.dc:creator: Xin Wang, Dan Luo, Jiayi Wang, Zhenghao Sun, Guoliang Cui, Yuxuan Chen, Tong Wang, Lirong Zheng, Yan Zhao, Lingling Shui, Guofu Zhou, Krzysztof Kempa, Yongguang Zhang, Zhongwei Chen

item.dc:title: Strain Engineering of MXene/CNT Hierarchical Porous Hollow Microsphere Electrocatalyst for High‐efficiency Lithium Polysulfides Conversion Process

item.title: Seven‐step Synthesis of All‐nitrogenated Sugar Derivatives Using Sequential Overman Rearrangements
item.dc:description: All‐nitrogenated sugars (ANSs), in which all hydroxy groups in a carbohydrate are replaced with amino groups, are anticipated to be privileged structures with useful biological activities. In their Communication (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202015141), Takaaki Sato, Noritaka Chida et al. report synthesis, transformation, and biological tests of ANS derivatives. The key to success is a seven‐step synthesis of ANSs by the sequential Overman rearrangement enabling formal simultaneous substitution of four or five hydroxy groups in monosaccharides with amino groups.
item.dc:creator: Yuya Okuyama, Mayu Kidena, Erina Kato, Sayaka Kawano, Koki Ishii, Kenta Maie, Kazuki Miura, Siro Simizu, Takaaki Sato, Noritaka Chida
item.content:encoded: All‐nitrogenated sugars (ANSs), in which all hydroxy groups in a carbohydrate are replaced with amino groups, are anticipated to be privileged structures with useful biological activities. The key to success is a seven‐step synthesis of ANSs by the sequential Overman rearrangement enabling formal simultaneous substitution of four or five hydroxy groups in monosaccharides with amino groups.

item.dc:title: Seven‐step Synthesis of All‐nitrogenated Sugar Derivatives Using Sequential Overman Rearrangements

item.title: Quantification of Redox Sites during Catalytic Propane Oxychlorination by Operando EPR Spectroscopy
item.dc:description: Operando EPR gets hot: In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013331), Guido Zichittella, Yevhen Polyhach, Javier Pérez‐Ramírez et al. demonstrate operando EPR spectroscopy as a pivotal technique to assess the oxidation state of CrPO4 and EuOCl catalysts during high‐temperature catalytic propane oxychlorination. As depicted in the cover, this enables the quantification of catalytically active centers, as the redox couple Cr3+ (gold)/Cr2+ (lilac), whose formation was correlated with the productivity of propylene.
item.dc:creator: Guido Zichittella, Yevhen Polyhach, René Tschaggelar, Gunnar Jeschke, Javier Pérez‐Ramírez
item.content:encoded: Operando EPR gets hot: In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013331), Guido Zichittella, Yevhen Polyhach, Javier Pérez‐Ramírez et al. demonstrate operando EPR spectroscopy as a pivotal technique to assess the oxidation state of CrPO4 and EuOCl catalysts during high‐temperature catalytic propane oxychlorination. As depicted in the cover, this enables the quantification of catalytically active centers, as the redox couple Cr3+ (gold)/Cr2+ (lilac), whose formation was correlated with the productivity of propylene.
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:title: Quantification of Redox Sites during Catalytic Propane Oxychlorination by Operando EPR Spectroscopy

item.title: Phenotypic Discovery of Neuroprotective Agents by Regulation of Tau Proteostasis via Stress‐Responsive Activation of PERK Signaling
item.dc:description: Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins such as tau protein. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013915), Seung Bum Park et al. perform a cell‐based phenotypic screening and identify a small molecule, SB1617, capable of suppressing abnormal assembly of tau protein under the ER stress. The label‐free target identification and mode of action studies revealed that SB1617 treatment leads to the restoration of proteostasis in a stress‐responsive manner.
item.dc:creator: Young‐Hee Shin, Hana Cho, Bo Young Choi, Jonghoon Kim, Jaeyoung Ha, Sang Won Suh, Seung Bum Park
item.content:encoded: Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins such as tau protein. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013915), Seung Bum Park et al. perform a cell‐based phenotypic screening and identify a small molecule, SB1617, capable of suppressing abnormal assembly of tau protein under the ER stress. The label‐free target identification and mode of action studies revealed that SB1617 treatment leads to the restoration of proteostasis in a stress‐responsive manner.
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:title: Phenotypic Discovery of Neuroprotective Agents by Regulation of Tau Proteostasis via Stress‐Responsive Activation of PERK Signaling

item.title: Induction of Chirality in a Metal–Organic Framework Built from Achiral Precursors
item.dc:description: Introduction of chirality in a metal–organic framework built from achiral precursors through achiral template‐driven self‐assembly is demonstrated by Qihui Chen, Maochun Hong et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013885). The driving force for chirality generation is a template‐driven kinetically controlled assembly process. The chirality generation process was identified in detail through transition state capture.
item.dc:creator: Dong Wu, Kang Zhou, Jindou Tian, Caiping Liu, Jiayue Tian, Feilong Jiang, Daqiang Yuan, Jian Zhang, Qihui Chen, Maochun Hong

item.title: Chemistry of Tertiary Carbon Center in the Formation of Congested C−O Ether Bonds
item.dc:description: A stereospecific nucleophilic substitution between tertiary alkyl bromides and tertiary alkyl alcohols is described in the Research Article by Toshiki Nokami, Takashi Koike, Manabu Abe, Eiji Shirakawa, Takashi Nishikata and co‐workers (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202010697). The entering alcohol formally attacks the C−Br bond to undergo a retentive substitution with formation of tertiary alkyl ethers.
item.dc:creator: Goki Hirata, Kentarou Takeuchi, Yusuke Shimoharai, Michinori Sumimoto, Hazuki Kaizawa, Toshiki Nokami, Takashi Koike, Manabu Abe, Eiji Shirakawa, Takashi Nishikata

item.dc:title: Chemistry of Tertiary Carbon Center in the Formation of Congested C−O Ether Bonds

item.title: Docking of CuI and AgI in Metal‐Organic Frameworks for Adsorption and Separation of Xenon
item.dc:description: Xenon separation from krypton by porous adsorbents is a sustainable technology for the production of small‐volume but high‐value noble gas. MOFs are designer xenon adsorbents to enhance their adsorption separation performance by tuning pore metrics, functionalities, and counter ions. In their Communication (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202015262), Yue‐Biao Zhang, Omar M. Yaghi, and co‐workers have developed a new methodology for post‐synthetic metalation of MOFs by harboring extra metal ions and counter ions for boosting the adsorption selectivity and uptake capacity simultaneously.
item.dc:creator: Haoze Wang, Zhaolin Shi, Jingjing Yang, Tu Sun, Bunyarat Rungtaweevoranit, Hao Lyu, Yue‐Biao Zhang, Omar M. Yaghi
item.content:encoded: Xenon separation from krypton by porous adsorbents is a sustainable technology for the production of small‐volume but high‐value noble gas. MOFs are designer xenon adsorbents to enhance their adsorption separation performance by tuning pore metrics, functionalities, and counter ions. In their Communication (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202015262), Yue‐Biao Zhang, Omar M. Yaghi, and co‐workers have developed a new methodology for post‐synthetic metalation of MOFs by harboring extra metal ions and counter ions for boosting the adsorption selectivity and uptake capacity simultaneously.
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:title: Docking of CuI and AgI in Metal‐Organic Frameworks for Adsorption and Separation of Xenon

item.title: Biomimetic Amino Acid Functionalized Phenazine Flow Batteries with Long Lifetime at Near‐Neutral pH
item.dc:description: Aqueous organic redox flow batteries (AORFB) are a promising electrochemical technology for large‐scale energy storage. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202014610), Pan Wang, Yunlong Ji et al. report a biomimetic, ultra‐stable AORFB utilizing an amino acid functionalized phenazine (AFP), thus demonstrating the importance of molecular engineering of redox‐active organics for robust redox‐flow batteries.
item.dc:creator: Shuai Pang, Xinyi Wang, Pan Wang, Yunlong Ji
item.content:encoded: Aqueous organic redox flow batteries (AORFB) are a promising electrochemical technology for large‐scale energy storage. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202014610), Pan Wang, Yunlong Ji et al. report a biomimetic, ultra‐stable AORFB utilizing an amino acid functionalized phenazine (AFP), thus demonstrating the importance of molecular engineering of redox‐active organics for robust redox‐flow batteries.
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:title: Biomimetic Amino Acid Functionalized Phenazine Flow Batteries with Long Lifetime at Near‐Neutral pH

item.title: Electrochemical Polymerization Provides a Function‐Integrated System for Water Oxidation
item.dc:description: Water oxidation is a key reaction in natural and artificial photosynthesis. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202015174), Mio Kondo, Shigeyuki Masaoka et al. report a facile strategy to integrate catalytic centers and hole transporters in one system, which is inspired by the natural water oxidation catalyst. A metal‐complex‐based precursor was electrochemically polymerized, and the obtained polymer‐based material exhibits excellent hole‐transporting ability and catalyzes water oxidation with high performance.
item.dc:creator: Hikaru Iwami, Masaya Okamura, Mio Kondo, Shigeyuki Masaoka

A metal‐complex‐based precursor was electrochemically polymerized, and the obtained polymer‐based material exhibits excellent hole‐transporting ability and catalyzes water oxidation with high performance.

item.dc:title: Electrochemical Polymerization Provides a Function‐Integrated System for Water Oxidation

item.title: Click‐Functionalization of a Poly(Tetrazine)‐co‐Fluorene‐Conjugated Polymer with a Series of trans‐Cyclooctene Derivatives
item.dc:description: The ability to post‐synthetically functionalize conjugated polymers by “plugging” various structures into the polymer backbone is demonstrated in the Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202010795) by Alex Adronov et al. using inverse electron demand Diels–Alder (IEDDA) chemistry on a poly(tetrazine) polymer backbone. A small library of polymers was rapidly prepared by reacting a series of trans‐cyclooctyne derivatives with the poly(tetrazine).
item.dc:creator: Vladimir Kardelis, Maria M. Denk, Alex Adronov

item.title: On‐POM Ring‐Opening Polymerisation of N‐Carboxyanhydrides
item.dc:description: The POMlymers are coming! Ruthless invading POMlymers (polyoxometalate–peptide hybrids) wreak havoc as biocidal agents preventing bacterial colonisation of (planetary) surfaces. In their Communication (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013563), Scott G. Mitchell, Rafael Martín‐Rapún, and co‐workers report an on‐POM polymerisation of N‐carboxyanhydrides which serves as an innovative platform to design hybrid materials with antimicrobial properties.
item.dc:creator: Héctor Soria‐Carrera, Isabel Franco‐Castillo, Pilar Romero, Santiago Martín, Jesús M. Fuente, Scott G. Mitchell, Rafael Martín‐Rapún
item.content:encoded: The POMlymers are coming! Ruthless invading POMlymers (polyoxometalate–peptide hybrids) wreak havoc as biocidal agents preventing bacterial colonisation of (planetary) surfaces. In their Communication (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202013563), Scott G. Mitchell, Rafael Martín‐Rapún, and co‐workers report an on‐POM polymerisation of N‐carboxyanhydrides which serves as an innovative platform to design hybrid materials with antimicrobial properties.
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:title: On‐POM Ring‐Opening Polymerisation of N‐Carboxyanhydrides

item.title: Geometry‐Directed Self‐Assembly of Polymeric Molecular Frameworks
item.dc:description: A solution‐processable thermally stable framework‐like material is reported by Stephen Z. D. Cheng et al. in their Communication (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202012117). The highly ordered mesoporous structures are prepared from T‐shaped rod–sphere–polymer amphiphiles through selective decomposition of the polymer chains.

item.dc:title: Geometry‐Directed Self‐Assembly of Polymeric Molecular Frameworks

item.title: Room‐Temperature Bistability in a Ni–Fe Chain: Electron Transfer Controlled by Temperature, Pressure, Light, and Humidity
item.dc:description: Stimuli‐responsive materials are important for the construction of molecular switches or sensors. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202012876), Mateusz Reczyński, Shin‐ichi Ohkoshi, Beata Nowicka and co‐workers present room temperature bistability in a CN‐bridged Ni–Fe coordination chain, which exhibits multiresponsive behavior with electron‐transfer transitions induced by temperature, light, pressure, and humidity. The material responds to these stimuli with measurable changes in magnetic properties and color.
item.dc:creator: Mateusz Reczyński, Dawid Pinkowicz, Koji Nakabayashi, Christian Näther, Jan Stanek, Marcin Kozieł, Justyna Kalinowska‐Tłuścik, Barbara Sieklucka, Shin‐ichi Ohkoshi, Beata Nowicka
